content: * *This article has multiple issues.** Please help **improve it** or discuss these issues on the **talk page**. *(Learn how and when to remove these messages)*This article **relies largely or entirely on a single source**. Relevant discussion may be found on the talk page. Please help improve this article by introducing citations to additional sources. *Find sources:* "SIBOR" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(December 2016)*This article **possibly contains original research**. Please improve it by verifying the claims made and adding inline citations. Statements consisting only of original research should be removed. *(December 2016)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)*This article **needs additional citations for verification**. Please help improve this article by adding citations to reliable sources. Unsourced material may be challenged and removed. *Find sources:* "SIBOR" – news **·** newspapers **·** books **·** scholar **·** JSTOR *(December 2016)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* *(Learn how and when to remove this message)* **SIBOR** stands for **Singapore Interbank Offered Rate** and is a daily [reference rate](/wiki/Reference_rate) based on the [interest rates](/wiki/Interest_rates) at which [banks](/wiki/Bank) offer to lend *unsecured* funds to other banks in the [Singapore](/wiki/Singapore) wholesale [money market](/wiki/Money_market) (or [interbank market](/wiki/Interbank_market)). It is similar to the widely used LIBOR ([London Interbank Offered Rate](/wiki/London_Interbank_Offered_Rate)), and [Euribor](/wiki/Euribor) (Euro Interbank Offered Rate). Using SIBOR is more common in the Asian region and set by the Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS). SIBOR comes in 1-, 3-, 6-, or 12-month tenure. At the end of the tenure, the borrowing bank returns the borrowed fund to the lending bank. The 3-month SIBOR is the most popular rate that loans are pegged to and has been hovering below around 1% in the past few years. Many [floating rate mortgages](/wiki/Adjustable-rate_mortgage) in the country are pegged to SIBOR due to its transparency. Alternatives to SIBOR include SOR, Fixed-rate mortgages, Combos (Combination of SIBOR and SOR). Although they may be higher or lower than SIBOR at any point of time, they usually move in tandem with the direction of SIBOR and are used by banks to help price loans. SIBOR is being discontinued, with the 6-month SIBOR rate being discontinued with effect from 31 March 2022, and the rest of SIBOR to be discontinued with effect from 31 December 2024. SIBOR will be functionally replaced by SORA (Singapore Overnight Rate Average). - [Adjustable-rate mortgage](/wiki/Adjustable-rate_mortgage) - [Fixed-rate mortgage](/wiki/Fixed-rate_mortgage) - [Singapore Swap Offer Rate (SOR)](/wiki/Singapore_Swap_Offer_Rate_(SOR)) - [Euribor](/wiki/Euribor) - [TIBOR](/wiki/TIBOR) - [Prime rate](/wiki/Prime_rate) - [TED spread](/wiki/TED_spread) - [LIBOR-OIS spread](/wiki/Overnight_indexed_swap) - [LIBOR](/wiki/LIBOR) - [HIBOR](/wiki/HIBOR) - [SAIBOR](/wiki/SAIBOR) - Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) This Asian bank-related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e This Singapore-related article is a stub. You can help Wikipedia by expanding it. - v - t - e
title: SIBOR
